attributes.label: Document delivery
attributes.title: Document delivery
attributes.description:
Document Delivery is a service available to Temple University faculty, distance learners and students with disabilities. This service enables you to request scans from print items owned by Temple University Libraries to be sent to you electronically.

How to request electronic document delivery

For faculty

Books: You may request scans of up to 20% of a book (capped at 50 pages) by signing in through the My Library Account in Library Search.

Journal Articles: You must make one unique request for each individual serial article you wish to have scanned.

For distance learners

Books: You may request scans of up to 20% of a book (capped at 50 pages) by creating and signing into your ILLiad account.

Journal Articles: You must make one unique request for each individual serial article you wish to have scanned.

For students with disabilities

Students who require additional assistance are required to register with Disability Resources and Services before submitting your electronic document delivery request.

Books: You may request scans of up to 20% of a book (capped at 50 pages) by creating and signing into your ILLiad account.

Journal Articles: You must make one unique request for each individual serial article you wish to have scanned.

When will I receive my electronic document?

Once the request has been made, library staff will locate and deliver a link to a pdf of the requested material directly to your email.

  • For items that are at Charles, Ambler, or the Health Sciences Libraries, we will supply a scan within 1-3 business days.
  • If the requested item is missing, checked out, or not owned, and you already have an ILLiad account, Document Delivery will submit an Interlibrary Loan request to our partner libraries.
  • We recommend that any member of our Temple community intending to use Document Delivery take a moment to register for your ILLiad account, open to all current Temple faculty, staff, and students. Turnaround times for items requested via Interlibrary Loan are dependent on the lender’s ability to supply us with the requested document(s).

attributes.label: Open Access Publishing Fund
attributes.title: Open Access Publishing Fund
attributes.description:
Through the Open Access Publishing Fund, we support faculty who would like to publish in an open access journal but do not have the funds to cover an article processing fee.

The Libraries’ goal in starting an Open Access Publishing Fund is to promote new forms of scholarly communication. There are a rising number of high-quality open access publishers whose business model depends on the fees they collect from authors. Authors are increasingly interested in making their work available open access, as it helps them reach new and wider audiences. However, the costs involved can be a deterrent. We hope this Fund will help remove this financial barrier, encouraging authors to experiment with new and innovative publishing models.

The Open Access Publishing Fund is open to all current Temple faculty members. Current postdoctoral fellows and graduate students may also apply, as long as there is at least one faculty member listed as a co-author on the article.

How to apply

Authors with a journal article that has been accepted or is under consideration by an open access publisher are encouraged to apply. Authors simply fill out a brief application form with their information, a copy of the article, and a copy of the journal acceptance letter (if available).

Funds will be available on a first come, first served basis. **As of February 1, 2019, the OA Publishing Fund has been exhausted, and we are no longer accepting applications for this fiscal year (July 1, 2018–June 30, 2019). Please check back after July 1, 2019.**

The Libraries will aim to make a final decision regarding the application within two weeks’ time. If the request is approved, Libraries will transfer funds to authors’ research fund or departmental account. The Libraries cannot reimburse authors or pay publishers directly.

Applicant eligibility

  • Applicants must be a current Temple University faculty member OR a current postdoctoral fellow/resident/graduate student with a faculty member listed as a co-author.
  • Applicants with external grant funding that could cover, either in whole or in part, the cost of any publication and processing fees are ineligible.
  • Applicants must agree to deposit a copy of their publication in our Digital Library, or any future library repository.

Publication eligibility

  • The publication must take the form of a peer-reviewed journal article.
  • Many subscription journals now offer an open access option in which authors can chose to pay a fee to make their article open access. These publications are sometimes called “hybrid” open access journals. Articles in “hybrid” journals are not supported.
  • The journal must be listed in the Directory of Open Access Journals (DOAJ). The DOAJ is a community-curated online directory that indexes high quality, open access, peer-reviewed journals.
  • The publisher must be a member of the Open Access Scholarly Publishing Association (OASPA), or clearly follow the membership criteria of the organization.
  • Because the Libraries already cover 50% of the APC for BioMed Central journals, these journals are not eligible.

Additional stipulations

  • Each applicant may request up to $1,500 total per fiscal year. This amount may be split across multiple applications so long as funds are available.
  • For articles with multiple Temple authors, the per article payment is capped at $3,000.
  • Funding will cover publication and processing fees only. Funds may not be used for reprints, color illustration fees, non-open access page charges, permissions fees, web hosting for self-archiving, or other expenses not directly related to open access fees.
  • For applicants who have not yet submitted for publication, requests will be conditionally approved awaiting official acceptance by the publisher. All conditional approvals will expire six months after notification. Applicants must provide a copy of the acceptance letter before the invoice is processed.
  • Fees are prorated for multi-authored articles. Co-authors from outside of Temple are not supported. If an article includes non-Temple authors, the APC will be divided equally among all authors and then the Temple authors’ portion will be funded. For example, if the APC is $2000, and there are four authors, two of whom are from Temple, the authors can apply for $1000 from the fund ($500 each).

Attribution requirement

  • Authors who receive support must include the following statement in their acknowledgements: Publication of this article was funded in part by the Temple University Libraries Open Access Publishing Fund.
attributes.access_description: Contact Mary Rose Muccie (maryrose.muccie@temple.edu) or Annie Johnson (annie.johnson@temple.edu).

attributes.label: Textbook Affordability Project
attributes.title: Textbook Affordability Project
attributes.description:
If you are a faculty member or course instructor, consider applying to Temple University Libraries' Textbook Affordability Project (TAP). The purpose of this grant is to facilitate reworking of traditional syllabi by experimenting and innovating without traditional textbooks to find new and less costly ways to deliver learning materials to students. Examples of proposals have included incorporating Open Education Resources and already licensed online content that is available to all members of the institution.

Application Requirements

  • Submit an online application including a narrative that identifies your process for adopting more affordable course material.

Program Requirements

  • Attend orientation workshop
  • Consult with subject librarian and archivist
  • Deposit reworked syllabus into Temple University Libraries’ Institutional Repository
  • Attend farewell lunch
  • Submit evaluation form

Selection Criteria

  • Potential savings to Temple students
  • Transferability of the project to other courses
  • Well-articulated evaluation plan
  • Adheres to Temple University accessibility standards

attributes.label: North Broad Press
attributes.title: North Broad Press
attributes.description: We are here to support our affiliates' creation of scholarly publications. We provide consultations about general publishing questions, and we publish journals, conference proceedings, books, and textbooks through our North Broad Press imprint.

attributes.label: Borrow from another library
attributes.title: Borrow from another library
attributes.description:
If you’re looking for something that Temple doesn’t own or is currently checked out, you can borrow books from other libraries through ILLiad and E-ZBorrow. Although ILLiad has more types of resources available, we recommend you try E-ZBorrow first since it has a quicker turnaround and longer loan periods.

How to Use E-ZBorrow

Log in to the E-ZBorrow site with your 9-digit Temple ID number. Search for your item and follow prompts to select the book and a location for pickup. Books are typically received in 3-5 business days. Loans are for 12 weeks, with no renewals, and are listed on your TU Library Account.

How to Use ILLiad

Log in to the ILLiad site with your TU Accessnet login. Select the type of material you are looking for under “New Request” on the left hand menu. After you submit your request, you will be notified via email when the material is ready for pickup. All due dates, renewal periods, and special conditions for material borrowed are determined by the lending institution. Material borrowed via ILLiad is subject to recall at any time. You can track materials borrowed through ILLiad in your MyLibrary Account.

ILLiad for Health Science Libraries Patrons

Patrons of the Health Sciences Libraries should use the following ILLiad links:

  • ILLiad for Ginsburg (HSL) Library Patrons
  • ILLiad for Podiatry Library Patrons

What are the differences between these two inter-library loan services?

EZborrow

ILLiad

Login type

9-digit Temple ID

TU Accessnet login

How it works

Search for Item

Fill out request form

Turnaround time

3-5 business days

Varies

Request confirmation

Immediate

Email notification when ready for pickup

What you can borrow

Books

Books

Book chapters

Conference proceedings

Journal articles

Scores

Video & sound recordings

Theses & dissertations

Borrowing from Other Temple Libraries

You can request materials from libraries on other Temple campuses. For example, as a Main Campus student you can request materials from Ambler and Health Sciences Libraries only. Go to the Library Catalog and find the item you want to request. Click on the Request button at the top of the record. Log in and follow the instructions. Remember that you cannot request materials from libraries on your campus.

Articles from other libraries will be delivered to your email account in PDF format.

All policies that apply to general circulation are applicable to materials borrowed from other Temple libraries.

Fines and replacement fees

Please see the borrowing periods chart for more information on fines and replacement fees for E-ZBorrow and ILLiad materials.
attributes.access_description: Call 215-204-0754 If you have questions about your requests, contact the Paley InterLibrary Loan Unit at or by email at teuill@temple.edu.

attributes.label: Borrow Books & DVDs
attributes.title: Borrow Books & DVDs
attributes.description:
Use your Owlcard to check out books, journals, and DVD/VHS at each of our Temple Libraries locations. Loan periods for items are listed below.

Renew items

Renew your books online through My Library Account or call any of our circulation desks.

Return items

Books and media may be returned at any TU library location. Reserve items must be returned to the library from which they were borrowed and may not be placed in the drop-bins.

Pay late & lost item fees

We charge fees for late, damaged, or lost items. These fees help us provide all of our users with consistent and reliable access to our collections.

Do you have questions about a late fee or lost item charge? We can work with you to resolve most fee issues at any service desk or call us at 215-204-0744. Acceptable forms of payment include credit/debit cards, Diamond Dollars and personal check. [If you have an Ambler Library question please come to our service desk or call us at 267-468-8648]

Reserves & non-circulating items

Some materials can only be used in the library, including reserves, items in our Special Collections Research Center, newspapers, microfilm, and maps.

Books are loaned for use in the library for up to three hours at a time and DVDs are loaned for use in the library for up to four hours.

attributes.label: Thesis/dissertation submission
attributes.title: Thesis/dissertation submission
attributes.description:
Q. What is an ETD?

A. ETD stands for “Electronic Thesis or Dissertation.” ETDs are often gathered by the degree-granting institution and deposited into digital repositories for public access.

Q. Where can I find ETDs from Temple University?

A. You can view Temple University ETDs in our digital collections repository. You can search the ETD collection using your name as keyword.

If you are unable to find your ETD and it has been more than six (6) months since your PhD or Master's degree was awarded, please email diglib@temple.edu with your full name, dissertation title, department, and date submitted so we can look into any issues. It is our understanding that ProQuest uploads your dissertation into their database within 6-8 weeks from the end of the semester.

Q. Is my dissertation listed in your online library catalog?

A. Yes. We copy the record describing your dissertation from the repository into the Library Search.

Q: I am a PhD student at Temple—must I submit my dissertation electronically?

A: Yes. As of September 2008, all PhD candidates must submit their dissertations electronically, and grant a limited non-exclusive license to Temple to include the dissertation in the University Libraries’ ETD repository.

Q: I am a Master’s degree student at Temple—do I need to submit my masters paper or thesis electronically?

A: Yes. As of August 2010, Master's degree candidates presenting a thesis (as opposed to a master's paper) are required to submit the thesis in electronic format and grant a limited non-exclusive license to Temple to include the thesis in the University Libraries’ ETD repository. Master's papers do not have to be submitted electronically.

Q. How do I submit my Temple dissertation or master’s thesis?

A. You will submit your dissertation or thesis through ProQuest. You can follow the instructions at the ProQuest ETD submittal site for Temple University. If the instructions are unclear or you have questions on how to prepare your thesis or dissertation, check the Temple dissertation instructions in the Dissertation and Thesis Handbook. Contact the Temple Graduate School if further help is needed either in formatting your paper, or to understand either your rights and the University’s graduation requirements—they are the experts in how to properly format and submit your thesis or dissertation.

Be sure that what you submit to the Graduate School and ProQuest is the final, fully proofread version. We cannot accept changes to the final submitted document.

Q: I do not want to give up my copyright!

A: Good news! You retain copyright of your work. The submittal mechanism only grants ProQuest and Temple limited non-exclusive licenses to reproduce the dissertation or master’s thesis. Please read the publishing agreement from ProQuest for full details.

Q: I want to publish my dissertation (or master’s thesis) as a book.

A: Granting Temple University a limited non-exclusive license to preserve and present your work in our institutional ETD repository does not prevent you from revising and publishing your research in whole or in part. Publishers generally regard the unrevised dissertation or master’s thesis as substantially different from a monograph.

Q: Will I receive royalties?

A: ProQuest will if you select the “traditional publishing” option during submittal. ProQuest will pay royalties of 10% of its net revenue from sales of the work, conditioned on the author maintaining a current address on record with ProQuest. Royalties will be paid when accrued earned royalties reach $25.00 USD. If, after 25 years, earned royalties do not accrue to at least $25.00 USD, ProQuest's royalty payment obligation will cease.

Be aware, however, that an open access copy of your work will be freely available online via the Libraries’ ETD repository. Temple University does not pay royalties. For more information on open access scholarship, view Temple’s Open Access Research Guide.

Q: I do not want my dissertation (or master’s thesis) publicly accessible via the web. What do I do?

A: For both dissertations and master's theses, making your contribution to scholarship publicly accessible is a requirement in order to receive the degree from Temple University. You may, however, request that an embargo be placed on your dissertation or thesis for up to two years, during which time the ETD would not be publicly accessible. At the end of the embargo period, your work will be available through ProQuest Dissertations & Theses, iParadigms and Dissertation Express, and a citation/abstract may appear in some indexes (e.g. SciFinder, MathSciNet, PsycINFO, etc.). In addition, the Libraries’ will automatically expose the scholarship in the ETD repository. If you need an extension, please contact the Graduate School.

Q: There are some images and diagrams from another author that I would like to include in my dissertation. Can I just include them?

A: Images, diagrams, or other materials from third-party sources may be under copyright. If you include copyrighted material of any sort in your dissertation/thesis, you MUST obtain the copyright holder's written permission for its inclusion and subsequent distribution. For instructions, and an example copyright permission letter, please see the Dissertation and Thesis Handbook. If you need help or have additional questions about copyright, contact your subject librarian.

Q. There is an error in my dissertation. What do I do?

A. Contact the Graduate School to discuss your options.

Q. I made a mistake in the submittal process. What do I do?

A. Contact the Graduate School and explain the nature of the mistake. In the case of an omitted file, such as an appendix or musical score, this can be resolved through them. For other errors, such as requesting that ProQuest not release or sell on your behalf print copies of your dissertation, you should ask that the Graduate School assist you in contacting ProQuest.

Q. Why is my name (or dissertation title) in all capital letters in the description?

A. We copy the submitted description without any editing. Formatting, such as capitalization, is carried over from the submission to ProQuest.

Q: What does the library do to promote wider visibility and reading of my dissertation or master’s thesis?

A. We upload the metadata describing your paper to three international databases:

  1. Temple University Library Search.
  2. The Networked Library of Digital Theses and Dissertations (NDLTD).
  3. WorldCat.

By listing the descriptive citation and abstract of your work in these international databases, anyone doing research in your specific area of study should turn up your work and find the embedded link back to to Temple’s ETD repository. Studies at other ETD repositories show that such exposure increases how often dissertations will be cited well beyond a simple listing in the fee-based ProQuest Dissertations database. Posting in a free open repository increases your impact on the scholarly world.

Q: Is a print copy of my dissertation (or master’s thesis) on the shelf somewhere in Paley Library?

A: If you submitted an ETD, we do not keep a paper or microfilm copy of the dissertation. For dissertations submitted prior to September 2008, we do have paper and microfilm copies at locations listed in the Temple University Library Search.

Q: Who keeps a backup copy of my dissertation then?

A: For dissertations or theses submitted electronically, the Libraries maintain, in a secure electronic storage system, an online disk backup of the PDF as submitted to us. That file is automatically backed up on additional disk arrays. The metadata and PDF included in the publicly searchable ETD repository is also backed up at two data centers in Ohio. We do not make or accept paper printouts of dissertations or theses submitted electronically. ProQuest also preserves microform copies of all electronically submitted dissertations.

attributes.label: Charge your device
attributes.title: Charge your device
attributes.description:
Temple Libraries provides the ability to charge your mobile devices and your laptop.

Charging lockers for mobile devices

Charging lockers are available for mobile devices (phones or tablets) that use a Micro-USB, USB-C or Lightning cable connector. The charging lockers are located in the following libraries.

  • Charles Library: TBD
  • Ginsburg Health Sciences Library: 1st floor by the Innovation Space
  • Krausz Library of Podiatric Medicine: Across from the information desk
  • Ambler: Next to the public-use printers

Instructions for using the lockers are posted next to or on top of the lockers. These charging lockers do not require coins to operate.

Charging bricks for laptops

Charging bricks are available for charging your laptop. These charging bricks can be used instead of a power outlet. The charging bricks are dispensed from kiosks located throughout Charles Library. Please note that you will need your laptop’s power cable in order to use the charging brick to charge your laptop.

All charging devices are available on a first come, first served basis. Contact a library tech assistant at the information desk with questions.

attributes.label: Research impact & scholarly credentials
attributes.title: Research impact & scholarly credentials
attributes.description:
We assist researchers to document the significance of their impact on research using tools that measure this impact. We can also help faculty better understand the tools that measure, or claim to measure, impact and their limitations.

Research impact is an important factor as researchers work to:

  • support applications for tenure or promotion
  • justify requests for grants and other funding
  • determine how their research is being used
  • identify who is using their work
  • identify other researchers, and potential collaborators, in their field

In addition, the Research Impact and Scholarly Credentials Reference Guide includes information, tools, and suggestions for documenting the significance of scholarly credentials and accomplishments.
attributes.access_description: Contact a subject librarian to show you how to track citations to your work and how to measure your research impact.

attributes.label: Systematic review service
attributes.title: Systematic review service
attributes.description:
Our Systematic Review Service is available for Health Sciences students, residents, and faculty and TUH house staff. This service provides opportunities to learn the best practices for searching, documenting the search for reproducibility, and managing the search results for systematic reviews or a variety of review types such as scoping reviews, rapid reviews, or network meta-analyses. Educational services are also available to provide guidance on how to appropriately conduct each stage of the review process.

If publishing, you can work with our team of expert systematic review librarians to perform the search.

The Systematic Review Service Research Guide includes everything you need to know about getting started with your next systematic review, scoping review, and other review types.
attributes.access_description: Contact Stephanie Roth or Ask A Librarian if you have additional questions or need assistance.

attributes.label: Booking requests
attributes.title: Booking requests
attributes.description:
You can submit a Booking request if you have a Faculty/Admin patron status.

Booking requests are a way for you to guarantee the availability of a film for use in your class on a specific date or dates.

You can place a request by logging into My Library Account and searching for the item you need for in class viewing. Once you select Request in the item record, you will see a Request booking option.

Booking requests do not allow for the transfer of items from campus to campus, the item you are booking must be picked up at the same location in which it is held.

The start date and the end date of your booking cannot exceed eight days and you cannot submit a request on the same day you plan to pick up the item from the library.

attributes.label: Get a library card (non-Temple)
attributes.title: Get a library card (non-Temple)
attributes.description:
Get a library card (non-Temple)

If you are a current faculty, student or staff at Temple University your Temple ID serves as your library card.

Community computer users

You can apply for a Community Computer User card by visiting the Service Desk in Charles Library.

You will need to bring with you a valid government issued photo ID, showing that you are at least 18 years old. The library staff will have you fill out a short application, which requires you to have an email address, and they will make a photocopy of your ID.

Your application will be reviewed by Temple Police and if approved your card will be ready for pick up at the Service Hub within two weeks.

Your Community Computers User card will allow you to log yourself onto one of our 12 community computers for two hours each day. You will also have access to charging stations, scanners, and cash printers that cost 10 cents per page for black and white ink and 50 cents per page for color ink.

Assistance is provided by Guest Technical Assistants during Community Computer Lab hours.

We also provide free wireless internet if you have your own device and a cell phone.

You can also browse our physical collection or watch films while in the library.

If you want to use a computer at the Ambler Library, you must speak to library staff. You will be required to follow the policy for Entrance to the University Libraries.

If you want to use a computer at the Ginsburg Health Sciences Library, you will be required to follow their Visitor Policy.

PA Residents

You can apply for a PA Residents borrowing card by visiting the Service Hub in Charles Library.

You will need to bring with you a valid government issued photo ID, showing that you are at least 18 years old. The library staff will have you fill out a short application and they will make a photocopy of your ID.

Your application will be reviewed by Temple Police and if approved your card will be ready for pick up at the Service Hub within two weeks.

Your PA Residents borrowing card will give you all of the same privileges as the Community Computers User card with the addition of checking out 10 books at a time. More detailed borrowing privileges are on the library’s website.

You can check your due dates and renew items needed longer by logging into My Library Account.

Visiting Scholars

If you are a Visiting Scholar you can request computer and library privileges through your sponsoring department. The department can request most privileges through the Guest Access Request System in TUPortal.

You can use our free wireless internet or Eduroam, if you are a student at a participating school.

attributes.label: Researcher profiles
attributes.title: Researcher profiles
attributes.description:
Librarians and subject matter experts can provide support for faculty to create and maintain researcher profiles in both internal and external profiling systems. Researcher profiles are important tools faculty can use in order to document their publications and scholarly activities.

At Temple

The Faculty Profile Builder allows you to track your scholarly activities and is a collaborative partnership between the Libraries, Information Technology Services (ITS), and Faculty Affairs.

The Libraries can provide support in setting up the Publications module of your profile.

For more information, contact your subject librarian.

Other profiles

As you work to establish, develop, and maintain your scholarly identity across multiple platforms, consider streamlining the way you present your research online. Sign up for an ORCID iD (Open Researcher and Contributor ID) and get a unique and persistent identifier to link together your publications, grants, personal website, social media, and any other profiles you have. Use this to distinguish yourself from other researchers and to ensure that your work is connected and recognized.

Want to learn more? The Libraries offer workshops and one-on-one consultations.

attributes.label: Request a purchase or electronic resource trial
attributes.title: Request a purchase or electronic resource trial
attributes.description: Members of the Temple University community may request the purchase of materials the Libraries do not currently own for inclusion in our collections. Requests will be considered in light of our collection development policy and the availability of the item in the desired format. A Temple University email address is required so that the Libraries can verify the requestor’s affiliation

attributes.label: Distance Learners Book Delivery
attributes.title: Distance Learners Book Delivery
attributes.description:
If you are a member of the Temple University online learning community, and live at least 40 miles from Temple’s main campus, you can request the loan of items owned by the Charles and Ambler libraries.

In partnership with the Office of Digital Education, the Charles and Ambler libraries allow you to borrow circulating items by signing into your ILLiad account and submitting a request.

Items requested from the Charles library will be mailed to your home address by UPS within one business day. Items requested from the Ambler campus library can take an additional 1-3 business days.

Your borrowing privileges are the same as the students attending on campus programs. It is your responsibility toreturn items you have checked out by their due date. Loss and any damage that occurs to these items prior to their return is also your responsibility.

If you need a particular book chapter or article, you can use our Document Delivery service to request a pdf scan be sent to you via your ILLiad account.
attributes.access_description: If you have any questions about book or document delivery you can email us at teuilll@temple.edu or call us at 215-204-0754

attributes.label: Request copies of SCRC materials
attributes.title: Request copies of SCRC materials
attributes.description:
Due to the fragile and rare nature of our materials, all duplication is performed by staff members.

While we make every attempt to accommodate duplication requests, making copies is inherently stressful to the originals. For this reason we’ve established limits to balance researchers’ needs with our obligation to preserve these resources. Depending on the condition, size, and quantity of materials requested, the SCRC reserves the right to refuse a copying order if, in its judgment,

  • fulfillment of the order would damage the item,
  • involve violation of U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U. S. Code), more information about copyright issues,
  • require reproduction of a major part of a book or archives collection (we will not reproduce more than 20 percent of any book, manuscript, or collection),
  • or entail the use of excessive staff time and resources.

Cameras use is allowed in the reading room. Please see this link for our cameras use policy.

For some collections, we require use of microfilm or digital copies in place of originals when film or digital copies are available and the originals are at risk.
attributes.access_description: Please email the Special Collections Research Center at scrc@temple.edu.
attributes.service_policies:
Duplication fees and payment

  • All requests must be accompanied by a signed Reproduction Request Form.
  • All orders must be paid in advance.  We accept payment by cash, check, or credit card.
  • Please make checks payable to "Temple University" and write SCRC in the memo line.  
  • International postage will be added at time of request.
  • If you wish to pay by credit card, there is a $15 minimum charge. We accept Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover, Diners Club, or JCB. To complete a credit card transaction, please call us at 215-204-8257, during business hours, Monday through Friday, from 8:30 am to 5:30 pm. Please do not leave credit card information on a voicemail or in an email.

Photocopy rates

  • $.25/page, selected by patron
  • $.35/page, mail order/selected by staff, up to 100 copies
  • $.40/page, mail order/selected by staff, up to 200 copies

Postage

  • up to 15 pages - $1.50
  • up to 25 pages - $1.75
  • up to 50 pages - $2.50
  • up to 100 pages - USPS rate

Rush fee (optional)

 

Rush turnaround for photographic, cassette, or video duplication may be available for a 50% additional charge with advance payment. Please contact SCRC staff for terms and costs.

 

Digital Scans

  • Scan per image: $5.00
  • STUDENT RATES (elementary school through graduate school): First 10 image prints or scans free—per project

For pricing on oversized or other unusual sized materials please contact a staff member.

 

Image format and delivery

 

Images will be scanned at 600 dpi or less and at the original size. TIFF and JPEG formats are available. JPEG files may be transmitted by email. TIFF images will be delivered via Temple University’s digital dropbox service, TUsafesend, or on a CD ROM, for a fee of $5.

 

Audio Duplication

 

Contact a staff member to ask about fees for cassette to digital (in-house) and reel-to-reel to digital (external vendor) audio duplication. 

 

Film/Video Duplication

 

The SCRC provides access to AV materials for in-house use and duplication to students, faculty, and guests for educational and research purposes. Fees and policies vary according to use.

 

For information about reproduction and licensing of some collections for publication or commercial use, please contact a staff member.  

 

The SCRC will provide user copies of footage that has been transferred to a duplicating master. If the footage has not been transferred to a duplicating master, the user will be required to bear the costs of reformatting prior to viewing. There are some formats that cannot be transferred in-house and must be sent to a vendor.

 

Preservation and access fees

  • Copying (in-house)/In-house use: $15/reel or tape; first 3 free
  • Additional screener DVDs: $25.00 per reel/tape
  • Copying by outside vendor: $400.00/30 min, $435.00/60 min
  • Copying pre-existing digital copy: $50/hour of product

Image Publication and Fees

 

Please use the Permission to Publish contract to request permission to publish images from our holdings.  A fee, in addition to reproduction costs, may be charged on published reproductions from our holdings. Publication includes film, video, videodisc, CD-ROM, web, and exhibit. The fee must be accompanied by a completed Permission to Publish contract for each use.

  • Temple Community: Fee waived
  • Non-Profit (with IRS tax-exempt number) $25.00; $10.00 for each additional
  • For-Profit $75.00; $50 for each additional

attributes.label: Alumni Services
attributes.title: Alumni Services
attributes.description:
Alumni may access any Temple library facility except the Law Library during open hours of operation. You will need an Alumni Card to show to the door guard. Visit the Office of Alumni Relations in 100 Sullivan Hall to obtain your Alumni Card.

Borrowing books and DVDs

The Alumni Card doubles as your library card and enables you to borrow ten books/dvds for a four-week period (DVDs circulate for one week, with a one week renewal).

Use of library resources

All alumni may use Library Search to locate books, journals, and other content available through Temple University Libraries.

Owing to license restrictions, alumni may only use the Temple University Library databases (e.g., EBSCO, Historical New York Times, Project JStor, etc.) on campus.

Interlibrary loan

Due to heavy demand for interlibrary loan services from current students and faculty, we are unable to extend access to ILLiad and E-ZBorrow to our alumni. We recommend that those in need of interlibrary loan services seek them out at any local community library. All public libraries have the capacity to receive materials from other libraries via interlibrary loan.

Consult with a librarian

We encourage our alumni to take advantage of our reference librarian's expertise. Use our Ask A Librarian service for assistance. See List of Subject Specialists to contact a reference librarian.

Accessing archives

Alumni can access archives housed in the Special Collections Research Center. Highlights include the university archives, home to yearbooks and historical photographs, and the Urban Archives, which document the social, economic, and physical development of the Philadelphia area from the mid-19th century to the present.

For more information: call 215-204-8257 or contact us.

Keeping in touch with Temple University Libraries

Alumni who want to read about recent developments at Temple University Libraries may request a subscription to Speaking Volumes, the newsletter for friends of the Libraries. Please send a request to Kimberly Nazaruk at kimberly.nazaruk@temple.edu.

Law and Health Sciences Libraries

Please contact each of these libraries individually to obtain additional information about their services for university alumni:

  • Law School: 215-204-7891
  • Health Sciences: 215-707-BOOK (707-2665)

attributes.label: Assistive Technology
attributes.title: Assistive Technology
attributes.description:
Temple Libraries offers a variety of assistive technology and adaptive equipment.

Adaptive equipment includes:

  • headphones with microphone
  • mini keyboard for one handed typing
  • 4 button touch pads for touch gesture mouse navigation
  • trackball mice for buttonless mouse navigation
  • text-to-speech software
  • CCTV with a screen reader device

The table below shows what adaptive software is available in what locations.

Most printers and and all print release computer stations meet required height and reach requirements ensuring unobstructed access to card swipes and output trays.
attributes.access_description:
At Charles Library, please visit the Loretta C. Duckworth Scholars’ Studio on the 3rd floor to use adaptive equipment.

 At Ginsburg, Krausz and Ambler Libraries, please check at the service or information desk for adaptive equipment.

attributes.label: Request materials from SCRC
attributes.title: Request materials from SCRC
attributes.description:
You are welcome to request SCRC materials for use in our Reading Room. To do so, you will need to create an SCRC Researcher Account and complete an online request form. Please also see “Registration and Security” for assistance with this process.

Our online tools include Library Search and our Finding Aids. We also have a large news clippings and photograph collection from the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin and Philadelphia Inquirer that you can request online for in-house use.

Please keep in mind that some of our materials are housed off-site and require at least 2 days advance notice for us to retrieve boxes for use in our reading room. Our staff will contact you if materials will not be ready by your preferred visit date.

Finally, while we are constantly striving to increase the discoverability of our materials, our website only covers a small portion of our actual collections and holdings—which is over 90,000 linear feet, many terabytes, and growing. If you don't find what you are looking for on our website, we encourage you to visit, call, or email us.

How to request materials in Library Search

  1. Identify and navigate to the Library Search record for an item you’re interested in using.
  2. Click on the “Request from Special Collections” link (under the “Request” column).
  3. Log in to your SCRC Researcher Account and complete the reading room request form.
  4. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time.
  5. Click the “Submit Request” button.

How to request materials listed in our online finding aids

  1. To locate finding aids, use Library Search at the top right corner of any website page.
  2. Enter your search terms and select the link from the search results, or click “Browse All Finding Aids.”
  3. Once in the Finding Aid, click the link in the upper right hand corner of the page that says “Request materials from Special Collections Research Center.” You will be prompted to log into your SCRC Researcher Account.
  4. Complete the archival reading room request form. Be sure to include the collection id in the Call Number field and the box number.
  5. Please submit a new request for each box you would like to see.
  6. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time
  7. Click the “Submit Request” button.

How to request newspaper clippings and photographs

  1. Navigate to the finding aid of Philadelphia Evening Bulletin Philadelphia Evening Bulletin News Clipping (SCRC 169) or Photograph Collection (SCRC 170); or the Philadelphia Inquirer News Clippings (SCRC 171) or Photograph Collection (SCRC 172).
  2. Once in the finding aid, click the link in the upper right hand corner of the page that says “Request materials from Special Collections Research Center.” You will be prompted to log into your SCRC Researcher Account.
  3. Complete the archival reading room request form. Enter the subject or name of the clippings you would like to see.
  4. For faster request processing, you must submit a new request for each subject or name.
  5. Enter the date of your visit by clicking on the small calendar icon next to the date field, or manually enter the dates. You may also select “Keep For My Review” if you wish to submit the request at a later time.
  6. Click the “Submit Request” button.

After submitting a request

Staff will pull the envelopes and/or photographs and place them on hold for you in the SCRC Reading Room.
attributes.access_description: If you don't find what you are looking for on our website, we encourage you to visit, call, or email us.

attributes.label: Doing research in the SCRC
attributes.title: Doing research in the SCRC
attributes.description:
In-person research at the SCRC

The best way to perform research using SCRC materials is to visit us in person. Students and researchers are welcome to request materials to use in the Reading Room. If it your first time visiting us, you’ll need to register for an SCRC Researcher Account.

Our collections are maintained in closed stacks and do not circulate, and all materials requested (except microforms) may be used only in the Reading Room.

Please be aware that many of our collections may be housed off-site at the Library Depository, and require up to two business days to retrieve. Please contact us in advance so that materials may be relocated to the reading room for your visit.

Remote reference assistance

If you cannot visit us in person, we invite you to contact the SCRC staff for reference assistance.

In all reference requests, please include your name and complete contact information, as well as your specific question. You may email, submit a request on our Ask SCRC page, call (215-204-8257), or write us (SCRC, Charles Library, Temple University Libraries, 1900 N. Thirteenth St., Philadelphia, PA 19122).

Please understand that due to staffing constraints, we are not able to provide in-depth research services. Questions are addressed in the order in which they are received, and response time will vary.

Research Assistance

The SCRC staff is not able to provide research services, except to Temple University administration.

The SCRC has only a few resources relevant to genealogical researchers, and some of those are restricted due to privacy and confidentiality issues. However, for remote researchers, SCRC staff will look up 4 biographical/genealogical entries per researcher, annually. Researchers interested in more than 4 entries per year are encouraged to visit our reading room to conduct their own research, where the 4 entry limit does not apply, during our normal hours of operation, Monday-Friday, 8:30am-5:30pm.

SCRC Research Guides

Guides to select topics and subjects available for research in the Special Collections Research Center can be found on this page. More will be added soon.

These guides represent a small portion of the possible research topics in our collections. Please contact us for research assistance or to request to view these materials in our reading room.

  • Military History resources
  • LGBTQ resources

How to Cite SCRC Materials

In all cases, researchers must cite the SCRC as the source with the appropriate credit line provided below:

[Description and date of item], [Box/folder number], [Collection title], [Collection ID], Special Collections Research Center, Temple University Libraries, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

If the material is under copyright, researchers must cite all copyright information and comply with all other terms or restrictions that may be applicable to that material.
